Question: A 65-year-old woman undergoing scoliosis surgery is on TIVA with stable MEPs and SEPs. The anesthesiologist considers substituting a long-acting nonselective beta-blocker for an esmolol infusion used for heart rate control. Which risk is most relevant to neuromonitoring?
OptionA: Long-acting beta-blockers are easier to titrate if hypotension compromises cord perfusion
OptionB: Long-acting beta-blockers may cause hypotension that is slower to reverse, making it harder to promptly correct perfusion-related neuromonitoring changes
OptionC: Esmolol always abolishes MEPs
OptionD: Beta-blockers have no hemodynamic effect
Explanation: Longer-acting nonselective beta-blockers are less easily titrated and reversed than esmolol; hypotension triggered by such agents is harder to correct quickly if neuromonitoring signals indicate compromised cord perfusion.[web:21][web:27][web:134]

Question: A 29-year-old man has recurrent episodes of staring and lip smacking. Video-EEG shows focal seizures originating from the left temporal lobe with rhythmic theta activity. Interictal EEG reveals independent bilateral temporal spikes. MRI shows left mesial temporal sclerosis. Which statement is most accurate regarding surgical prognosis?
OptionA: Bitemporal spikes preclude surgery regardless of ictal onset
OptionB: Consistent unilateral left temporal ictal onset with concordant MRI supports consideration of left temporal lobectomy despite bilateral interictal spikes
OptionC: Surgery must be bilateral
OptionD: EEG is nonlocalizing
Explanation: Unilateral ictal onset with concordant structural pathology (left mesial temporal sclerosis) can justify epilepsy surgery even in the presence of bilateral interictal spikes, which do not automatically preclude resection.[web:20][web:23]

Question: An intraoperative system displays cortical SEP peaks that appear broader and delayed after a notch filter at 60 Hz is activated. The underlying data acquisition parameters (sampling, high/low-pass filters) are unchanged. What is the most plausible "Explanation"?
OptionA: True physiologic slowing of conduction
OptionB: Phase distortion introduced by the notch filter, altering waveform shape and apparent peak timing
OptionC: Improved neural synchrony
OptionD: Increased stimulus intensity
Explanation: Notch filters can introduce phase distortion and affect the shape and timing of short-latency waveforms like SEPs; apparent broadening and delay of peaks may reflect filter effects rather than true physiologic change.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 34-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis develops an internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) on the right. On leftward gaze, the right eye fails to adduct and the left eye shows nystagmus. Convergence is intact. Which structure is affected?
OptionA: Right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
OptionB: Left MLF
OptionC: Right abducens nerve
OptionD: Left oculomotor nerve
Explanation: Right INO results from a lesion of the right MLF, interrupting signals from the left abducens internuclear neurons to the right oculomotor nucleus, impairing right eye adduction on contralateral gaze.[web:27]

Question: A 29-year-old woman with suspected multiple sclerosis has normal median SEPs but posterior tibial SEPs with prolonged central conduction time (spinal–cortical interval) and preserved peripheral responses. Clinical exam shows spastic paraparesis and sensory ataxia in the legs. Which conclusion is most appropriate?
OptionA: Peripheral neuropathy of the tibial nerves
OptionB: Central demyelination of long ascending sensory tracts serving the lower extremities
OptionC: Isolated cortical lesion sparing long tracts
OptionD: Thoracic radiculopathy
Explanation: Prolonged central conduction with normal peripheral responses in posterior tibial SEPs suggests central demyelination of dorsal column pathways, typical of spinal cord involvement in multiple sclerosis affecting lower-extremity projections.[web:41][web:48][web:118]

Question: During thoracic intramedullary tumor resection, lower extremity muscle MEPs become absent, but epidural D-wave amplitude recorded above the lesion remains at 95% of baseline. SEPs are unchanged. Postoperatively, the patient has severe paraparesis that gradually improves over months. Which principle does this case illustrate?
OptionA: D-wave amplitude is irrelevant to long-term outcome
OptionB: Preserved D-wave amplitude with absent MEPs predicts a high likelihood of substantial long-term motor recovery despite early postoperative weakness
OptionC: Absent MEPs always predict permanent paralysis
OptionD: SEP stability guarantees no motor deficits
Explanation: Preserved D-wave amplitude indicates intact corticospinal tract conduction; muscle MEP loss can reflect transient synaptic or segmental motor neuron dysfunction, and in such cases substantial long-term recovery is common despite early deficits.[web:24][web:27][web:33]

Question: A 58-year-old man with a seizure history controlled on levetiracetam undergoes spine surgery with MEP monitoring under TIVA. The team considers a modest ketamine bolus followed by low-dose infusion for analgesia. What is the best characterization of ketamine’s pro- or anti-seizure risk in this context?
OptionA: Strongly proconvulsant at all doses and contraindicated
OptionB: Generally safe at low–moderate doses in well-controlled epilepsy, with rare proconvulsant reports and careful monitoring advised
OptionC: Always antiseizure and used to treat status epilepticus
OptionD: No CNS effects at clinical doses
Explanation: Ketamine has complex effects but at low–moderate anesthetic doses is generally safe in patients with well-controlled epilepsy and is widely used in neuroanesthesia, though rare proconvulsant effects have been reported, so monitoring is prudent.[web:27][web:108]

Question: A 72-year-old woman with confusion and sepsis undergoes EEG. The recording shows generalized periodic discharges (GPDs) at 1–2 Hz without clear evolution. After treatment, both her mental status and GPDs improve. How are GPDs in this context best viewed?
OptionA: Always ictal and requiring anesthetic coma
OptionB: Patterns on an ictal–interictal continuum that can reflect severe encephalopathy and may or may not represent nonconvulsive seizures, requiring clinical correlation
OptionC: Benign variants
OptionD: Pathognomonic for CJD
Explanation: GPDs occurring in severe metabolic or septic encephalopathy lie on an ictal–interictal continuum; they may indicate increased seizure risk but do not invariably represent NCSE and must be interpreted in clinical context.[web:20][web:23][web:91]

Question: A technologist wants to reduce low-frequency baseline drift in SEPs while preserving cortical peaks. Currently, the high-pass filter is 1 Hz. Which new setting is most appropriate?
OptionA: High-pass 0.1 Hz
OptionB: High-pass 10–20 Hz
OptionC: Low-pass 30 Hz
OptionD: High-pass 100 Hz
Explanation: Raising the high-pass filter into the 10–20 Hz range can significantly reduce baseline drift and very slow activity while still preserving the main SEP components, which have higher frequency content.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 65-year-old man with severe cervical spondylotic myelopathy presents with a spastic gait, hand clumsiness, and decreased vibration sense in the legs. MRI shows cord compression at C4–C5. Which tracts are primarily responsible for his combination of spasticity and sensory ataxia?
OptionA: Anterior horn cells and spinothalamic tracts
OptionB: Lateral corticospinal tracts and dorsal columns
OptionC: Corticobulbar tracts only
OptionD: Spinocerebellar tracts only
Explanation: Cervical myelopathy commonly affects lateral corticospinal tracts, causing spastic weakness, and dorsal columns, causing impaired vibration and proprioception, resulting in sensory ataxia and gait disturbance.[web:27][web:41]

Question: During thoracic aortic surgery with segmental artery sacrifice, posterior tibial SEPs are used for spinal cord monitoring. After clamping a key segmental artery, P37 amplitude declines by 60% and latency increases by 2 ms. What does the ACNS guideline-based evidence suggest about this SEP change?
OptionA: It has no predictive value for neurologic outcome
OptionB: It is associated with increased risk of postoperative spinal cord deficit and should prompt corrective interventions such as raising MAP or reconsidering segmental artery sacrifice
OptionC: It guarantees postoperative paraplegia
OptionD: It only reflects anesthetic depth
Explanation: Evidence-based guidelines indicate that SEP changes of ≥50% amplitude reduction and/or ≥10% latency increase correlate with higher risk of neurologic deficits and warrant immediate intraoperative interventions.[web:30][web:33][web:20]

Question: During lumbar pedicle screw placement, triggered EMG thresholds are measured with monopolar stimulation. One right L5 screw elicits a compound muscle action potential in tibialis anterior at 5 mA, while all others require ≥12 mA. What is the best interpretation?
OptionA: 5 mA indicates a safe screw far from the root
OptionB: 5 mA is in the suspicious range suggesting a thin medial wall or impending medial breach near the L5 root and should prompt careful evaluation
OptionC: Higher thresholds indicate more danger
OptionD: Triggered EMG thresholds are unrelated to screw position
Explanation: Low thresholds (typically <5–6 mA) for triggered EMG suggest proximity to or breach of the medial pedicle wall and nerve root; intermediate values warrant heightened suspicion and correlation with imaging and anatomy.[web:27][web:33][web:135]

Question: A 61-year-old man undergoing thoracic decompression with MEP monitoring is maintained on 0.6 MAC sevoflurane, 50% nitrous oxide, and a low-dose propofol infusion. MEPs are small and unreliable, while SEPs are recordable. What anesthetic adjustment is most likely to improve MEP reliability?
OptionA: Increase sevoflurane to 1.0 MAC
OptionB: Discontinue nitrous oxide and reduce sevoflurane toward 0–0.3 MAC while increasing propofol and opioid-based TIVA
OptionC: Stop propofol and maintain volatile agents only
OptionD: Add benzodiazepines
Explanation: Both nitrous oxide and volatile anesthetics depress MEPs; moving toward low- or no-volatile TIVA and eliminating nitrous oxide improves corticospinal excitability and MEP amplitude.[web:24][web:27][web:134]

Question: A 30-year-old man with suspected psychogenic non-epileptic events has a typical spell captured on video-EEG: asynchronous pelvic thrusting, variable limb movements, and preserved pupillary responses. EEG shows intact background with only muscle artifact. Which feature strongly favors PNES over epileptic seizures?
OptionA: Generalized tonic stiffening
OptionB: Lack of ictal EEG change with preserved normal background during the clinical event
OptionC: Postictal suppression on EEG
OptionD: Stereotyped tonic–clonic pattern
Explanation: In PNES, clinical events lack associated ictal EEG changes and background remains normal; adequate technical recording with preserved background during spells strongly supports a psychogenic origin.[web:20][web:23][web:91]

Question: A technologist notices that BAEP Wave I is difficult to identify due to overlapping cochlear microphonic (CM) potentials. Switching from rarefaction-only clicks to alternating polarity (rarefaction–condensation) averages reduces CM but slightly decreases Wave I amplitude. Why is alternating polarity used in this situation?
OptionA: To reverse all neural components
OptionB: To cancel polarity-sensitive CM while preserving relatively polarity-insensitive neural BAEP components, improving clarity of Waves I–V overall
OptionC: To double the latency of BAEP peaks
OptionD: To eliminate all noise
Explanation: Alternating click polarity tends to cancel cochlear microphonic potentials, which invert with polarity, while neural BAEP components are much less affected, improving overall waveform interpretation despite some amplitude trade-off for Wave I.[web:22][web:131]

Question: A 54-year-old man has right homonymous hemianopia and alexia without agraphia after a left posterior cerebral artery stroke. He can write but cannot read, including his own writing. Which disconnection explains this syndrome?
OptionA: Disconnection of left visual cortex from left language areas
OptionB: Disconnection of right visual cortex from left language areas via damage to the splenium of the corpus callosum
OptionC: Disconnection of right motor cortex from Broca area
OptionD: Disconnection of cerebellum from basal ganglia
Explanation: Alexia without agraphia arises when right visual field information cannot reach left language areas due to a left occipital lesion plus splenial callosal damage, disconnecting right visual cortex from left angular gyrus.[web:27]

Question: A 45-year-old man with cervical myelopathy shows delayed median N20 and posterior tibial P37 latencies with normal peripheral responses. Intraoperatively, after cervical decompression, both N20 and P37 latencies shorten and amplitudes increase modestly. What is the most appropriate interpretation?
OptionA: Worsening dorsal column function
OptionB: Improved dorsal column–medial lemniscus conduction consistent with effective decompression
OptionC: Anesthetic-induced SEP suppression
OptionD: Peripheral neuropathy progression
Explanation: Shortening of SEP latencies and increased amplitudes after decompression indicate improved conduction in dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathways and are considered a positive intraoperative sign.[web:30][web:131][web:33]

Question: During thoracic tumor resection, lower extremity MEPs gradually decline by 50% over 15 minutes without surgical manipulation in that interval. SEPs are unchanged. MAP has drifted from 85 to 60 mmHg. Which is the most appropriate interpretation?
OptionA: Focal dorsal column injury
OptionB: Anterior spinal cord hypoperfusion affecting motor pathways, with SEPs relatively preserved at this stage
OptionC: Anesthetic artifact only
OptionD: Peripheral neuropathy of the tibial nerves
Explanation: Motor tracts supplied by the anterior spinal artery are highly sensitive to ischemia; progressive MEP decline with hypotension and stable SEPs suggests anterior spinal hypoperfusion requiring MAP restoration.[web:24][web:27][web:33][web:117]

Question: A 69-year-old patient undergoing thoracic spine surgery with neuromonitoring becomes hypertensive. The anesthesiologist chooses clevidipine for blood pressure control. How does clevidipine’s pharmacology support neuromonitoring?
OptionA: Long-acting vasodilator allowing stable low blood pressure
OptionB: Ultra–short-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker enabling rapid titration of MAP with minimal CNS depression and quick reversibility if neuromonitoring changes occur
OptionC: Direct MEP enhancer
OptionD: GABA agonist inducing burst-suppression
Explanation: Clevidipine’s rapid onset/offset and peripheral vasodilatory action allow precise MAP control with minimal direct CNS effect, facilitating rapid adjustments if neuromonitoring suggests compromised perfusion.[web:27][web:134]

Question: A 63-year-old man with Alzheimer disease has an EEG showing generalized 4–7 Hz theta and intermittent 1–3 Hz delta activity without epileptiform discharges. How should this EEG be interpreted?
OptionA: Normal for age
OptionB: Nonspecific diffuse cerebral dysfunction consistent with advanced neurodegenerative or metabolic encephalopathy
OptionC: Diagnostic of generalized epilepsy
OptionD: Pathognomonic for CJD
Explanation: Generalized theta–delta slowing without epileptiform discharges is a nonspecific sign of diffuse cerebral dysfunction, consistent with advanced neurodegenerative disease such as Alzheimer or metabolic encephalopathy.[web:20][web:23]

Question: A technologist increases the sensitivity of the EEG display from 10 µV/mm to 5 µV/mm. How will this change affect the appearance of the background rhythm on the screen?
OptionA: Waveforms will appear half as tall
OptionB: Waveforms will appear twice as tall, although actual voltage is unchanged
OptionC: Frequency will be doubled
OptionD: Latency will shorten
Explanation: Increasing display sensitivity (smaller µV/mm value) causes a given voltage to produce a greater vertical deflection; waveforms appear taller even though their actual amplitude remains unchanged.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 59-year-old patient presents with bilateral leg weakness, spasticity, and loss of vibration and proprioception in the feet, with preserved pain and temperature. MRI shows a long segment of dorsal and lateral column signal change in the cervical and upper thoracic cord. Serum tests reveal low vitamin B12. Which diagnosis is most likely?
OptionA: Anterior spinal artery infarction
OptionB: Subacute combined degeneration
OptionC: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
OptionD: Multiple sclerosis
Explanation: Subacute combined degeneration due to vitamin B12 deficiency affects dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, causing sensory ataxia and spastic paraparesis with relative sparing of spinothalamic-mediated pain and temperature.[web:41][web:48]

Question: In an aortic repair case, posterior tibial SEPs are monitored. Under stable anesthetic conditions, P37 amplitude decreases by 60% and latency increases by 1.5 ms on both sides after segmental artery clamping. MAP remains at 80 mmHg. What is the recommended neuromonitoring-based response?
OptionA: Continue surgery without change because SEPs are still present
OptionB: Issue an alert, consider raising MAP, re-evaluating clamp position, or adding distal perfusion to improve spinal cord blood flow
OptionC: Stop SEP monitoring and rely on MEPs only
OptionD: Increase anesthetic depth
Explanation: SEP changes of ≥50% amplitude reduction and/or ≥10% latency increase meet commonly used alert criteria and indicate increased risk of spinal cord ischemia, prompting hemodynamic optimization and surgical reassessment.[web:20][web:30][web:33]

Question: During tumor resection near the spinal accessory nerve in the posterior cervical triangle, free-running EMG from the trapezius shows sustained high-frequency discharges when traction is applied. MEPs are not used. What intraoperative management is most appropriate?
OptionA: Ignore EMG since MEPs are absent
OptionB: Notify the surgeon and request reduction of traction or repositioning of instruments near the spinal accessory nerve
OptionC: Administer neuromuscular blocker to stop EMG activity
OptionD: Stop EMG monitoring
Explanation: Continuous neurotonic EMG activity from the trapezius indicates acute irritation of the spinal accessory nerve; the appropriate response is to alert the surgeon and adjust traction or instrumentation to reduce risk of permanent injury.[web:27][web:136]

Question: A 56-year-old man undergoing thoracic scoliosis correction with MEPs and SEPs develops significant agitation and hypertension. Instead of increasing volatile anesthetic, the anesthesiologist adds dexmedetomidine at 0.7 µg/kg/hr. MEP and SEP amplitudes remain adequate. Which advantage of dexmedetomidine is most relevant here?
OptionA: It is a potent GABA agonist causing deep cortical suppression
OptionB: It provides sedation via alpha-2 agonism with limited additional depression of corticospinal excitability compared with increasing volatile or GABAergic agents
OptionC: It is a neuromuscular blocker improving EMG
OptionD: It selectively suppresses SEPs but not MEPs
Explanation: Dexmedetomidine’s alpha-2 mediated sedation preserves cortical and spinal excitability better than higher doses of propofol, benzodiazepines, or volatile agents, making it advantageous when neuromonitoring stability is essential.[web:21][web:27][web:134]

Question: A 37-year-old woman with suspected absence seizures undergoes EEG with hyperventilation. During hyperventilation, she develops several 10–15 second episodes of staring associated with generalized 3 Hz spike–wave discharges. After hyperventilation stops, both seizures and discharges resolve. Which diagnosis is most consistent with these findings?
OptionA: Temporal lobe epilepsy with complex partial seizures
OptionB: Typical absence epilepsy
OptionC: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures
OptionD: Metabolic encephalopathy
Explanation: Typical absence seizures show generalized 3 Hz spike–wave discharges, often provoked by hyperventilation, with brief behavioral arrest and rapid recovery, consistent with absence epilepsy.[web:20][web:23]

Question: An intraoperative system displays SEPs with a sweep of 50 ms/division. The neurophysiologist requests changing to 10 ms/division to better evaluate early peaks. How does this change affect interpretation?
OptionA: True SEP latencies are altered
OptionB: The time axis is compressed, magnifying early portions of the waveform and improving visual resolution of early peaks without changing actual latencies
OptionC: SEP amplitudes are doubled
OptionD: Noise is eliminated
Explanation: Adjusting sweep speed changes only the visual scaling of time; shorter sweeps magnify early segments, allowing more precise visual identification of early peaks without altering true peak latencies.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 64-year-old man with atrial fibrillation presents with acute vertigo, right-sided limb ataxia, right facial numbness, left body pain and temperature loss, right Horner syndrome, and hoarseness. MRI confirms a right lateral medullary infarct extending to the restiform body. Which arterial territory is most commonly implicated, and which pathway disruption accounts for the contralateral body pain and temperature deficit while sparing proprioception and vibration sense?
OptionA: Anterior spinal artery with medial medullary syndrome
OptionB: Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) with lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome; spinothalamic tract interruption after anterior commissure decussation
OptionC: Basilar artery perforators causing pontine lacune
OptionD: Superior cerebellar artery affecting cerebellar hemisphere
Explanation: Lateral medullary syndrome from PICA or vertebral artery occlusion disrupts the lateral medulla, including the crossed spinothalamic tract (contralateral body pain/temperature loss), spinal trigeminal nucleus (ipsilateral facial sensory loss), descending sympathetic fibers (ipsilateral Horner), and inferior cerebellar peduncle (ataxia). Proprioception and vibration are spared because dorsal columns remain intact until medullary decussation. Medial structures (corticospinal, medial lemniscus) are unaffected, avoiding hemiparesis (standard brainstem vascular syndromes). Distractor A describes medial medullary syndrome, which affects corticospinal and medial lemniscus tracts, producing contralateral hemiparesis and loss of proprioception, not the sensory dissociation seen here.

Question: During repair of a descending thoracic aortic aneurysm with partial left heart bypass, posterior tibial SEP monitoring shows normal popliteal fossa potentials but bilateral cortical P37 amplitude reduction to 30% of baseline with 15% latency prolongation after distal aortic cross-clamping. Median SEPs and upper extremity responses remain stable. Which vascular supply compromise best explains this pattern of lower extremity central conduction deterioration?
OptionA: Anterior spinal artery territory ischemia affecting corticospinal tracts preferentially
OptionB: Interruption of critical segmental radicular arteries (e.g., artery of Adamkiewicz) reducing perfusion to thoracolumbar dorsal columns via posterior spinal arteries
OptionC: Peripheral lower extremity nerve ischemia from positioning
OptionD: Systemic hypotension causing global cortical suppression
Explanation: Bilateral symmetric lower extremity cortical SEP changes with preserved peripheral and upper extremity responses indicate thoracic dorsal column pathway compromise, typically from loss of radicular contribution to posterior spinal circulation. Anterior spinal artery ischemia would more prominently affect motor pathways (MEPs), while global effects would involve median SEPs (ACNS Guideline on intraoperative SEP monitoring). Distractor A is incorrect because anterior spinal artery ischemia affects motor tracts, not sensory, and would be reflected in MEPs rather than SEPs.

Question: In a 38-year-old patient undergoing resection of a C5–C7 intramedullary ependymoma, epidural D-wave amplitude is preserved at 70% of baseline throughout the case. However, bilateral upper extremity muscle MEPs are lost after central tumor debulking, while lower extremity MEPs decrease 40%. Which pathophysiologic mechanism and long-term motor prognosis are most consistent with this dissociation?
OptionA: Severe irreversible corticospinal axonal transection with high risk of permanent deficit
OptionB: Likely reversible anterior horn, interneuronal, or synaptic dysfunction with favorable prognosis for substantial recovery given D-wave preservation >50%
OptionC: Peripheral root avulsion requiring immediate surgical exploration
OptionD: Global anesthetic suppression necessitating TIVA adjustment
Explanation: D-wave amplitude >50% indicates maintained corticospinal axonal integrity; muscle MEP loss in this setting reflects transient segmental or synaptic depression rather than axonal destruction. Poor prognosis correlates with D-wave loss >50%, whereas preservation supports recovery potential despite muscle MEP absence (standard intramedullary tumor monitoring literature). Distractor A is incorrect because irreversible transection would be reflected in D-wave loss, not preservation.

Question: A 70-year-old patient with chronic hypertension and coronary disease undergoes lumbar instrumented fusion with TcMEP monitoring under propofol/remifentanil TIVA. Sevoflurane 0.4 MAC is introduced for blood pressure control. MEPs become unobtainable bilaterally within 10 minutes despite unchanged propofol rate and MAP 80 mmHg. Which primary mechanism explains this rapid deterioration?
OptionA: Minimal additional suppression at low MAC
OptionB: Volatile agent enhancement of GABA-A and glycine receptor inhibition causing profound desynchronization of cortical motor networks and spinal motoneuron excitability depression
OptionC: NMDA antagonism increasing excitability
OptionD: Opioid receptor potentiation
Explanation: Volatile agents produce steep, dose-dependent MEP suppression via enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, often abolishing responses at sub-MAC levels despite stable intravenous agents. This contrasts with TIVA's relative preservation and underscores volatile avoidance when reliable motor monitoring is required (standard anesthesia effects on IONM). Distractor A is incorrect because even low MAC volatiles cause significant MEP suppression, not minimal.

Question: During carotid endarterectomy with EEG monitoring, new ipsilateral frontal theta slowing appears after test clamping, progressing to polymorphic delta activity without amplitude attenuation. MAP is 70 mmHg. Which interpretation and initial intervention are most appropriate?
OptionA: Anesthetic deepening; increase agent delivery
OptionB: Early cerebral hypoperfusion; prompt MAP augmentation and consideration of shunt placement to prevent progression to suppression
OptionC: Benign drowsiness variant
OptionD: Focal seizure onset requiring benzodiazepine
Explanation: Progressive focal slowing post-clamping reflects evolving ischemia; early hemodynamic optimization can reverse changes and avoid severe attenuation. Bilateral anesthetic effects would be symmetric, while seizures typically show rhythmic evolution or spikes (standard EEG in carotid surgery). Distractor A is incorrect because anesthetic deepening would cause bilateral, not focal, slowing.

Question: BAEP monitoring during microvascular decompression uses 100 µs rarefaction clicks at 90 dB nHL. Wave I is poorly defined on one side. Switching to condensation polarity worsens Wave I, but alternating polarity improves overall waveform reproducibility. Which cochlear and artifact principle explains this polarity effect?
OptionA: Condensation always enhances Wave I
OptionB: Rarefaction typically produces larger Wave I via greater basilar membrane displacement; alternating polarity cancels stimulus artifact (cochlear microphonic) for better later wave definition
OptionC: Polarity affects Wave V latency only
OptionD: No polarity dependence exists
Explanation: Rarefaction polarity optimizes basal cochlear stimulation for Wave I; alternating averages reduce polarity-sensitive artifact, improving overall morphology (standard BAEP technical guidelines). Distractor A is incorrect because condensation clicks do not always enhance Wave I; rarefaction is generally preferred for Wave I clarity.

Question: A 55-year-old patient with vascular risk factors develops acute contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss to all modalities, and hemianopia without facial weakness. MRI shows a lacunar infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Which anatomic organization explains facial sparing despite body involvement?
OptionA: Corona radiata with diffuse fiber distribution
OptionB: Corticobulbar fibers diverge rostrally from the compact capsular corticospinal and thalamocortical tracts before pontine nuclei
OptionC: Medullary pyramid
OptionD: Midbrain peduncle
Explanation: Internal capsule lacunes affect tightly bundled body/limb fibers; corticobulbar tracts for face exit earlier, producing pure hemisyndrome without facial weakness unlike cortical or brainstem lesions (standard capsular stroke syndromes). Distractor A is incorrect because corona radiata lesions are more diffuse and less likely to spare the face.

Question: A 32-year-old woman with aquaporin-4 antibody-positive neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder presents with acute paraparesis and sensory level at T6. Posterior tibial SEPs show markedly reduced lumbar N22 and absent cortical P37 bilaterally with normal popliteal fossa responses. Median SEPs are normal. Which lesion characteristic best explains this pattern?
OptionA: Peripheral demyelinating neuropathy
OptionB: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis with predominant dorsal column involvement in thoracic cord
OptionC: Isolated cortical generators
OptionD: Brainstem lemniscal lesion
Explanation: NMOSD lesions are often centrally located and longitudinally extensive, frequently affecting dorsal columns in spinal cord; lower extremity changes reflect thoracic involvement, with upper extremity sparing due to cervical sparing (ACNS Guideline on evoked potentials in demyelinating disease). Distractor A is incorrect because peripheral neuropathy would affect popliteal responses, not just central conduction.

Question: During L4 pedicle screw placement for degenerative spondylolisthesis, triggered EMG stimulation yields reproducible CMAPs in quadriceps and tibialis anterior at 6 mA threshold, while adjacent levels require >20 mA. Intraoperative imaging shows acceptable screw position. Which risk assessment and recommended action are most appropriate?
OptionA: Safe placement as threshold >5 mA
OptionB: Intermediate to high concern for medial or inferior pedicle breach with root proximity; recommend screw repositioning or advanced imaging despite normal fluoroscopy
OptionC: Lateral breach indicated
OptionD: Technical artifact; proceed unchanged
Explanation: Thresholds 6–10 mA represent caution zone suggesting bony compromise and nerve contact; revision reduces injury risk even with apparently normal imaging (ACNS Guideline on triggered EMG). Distractor A is incorrect because thresholds <10 mA are not considered safe for screw placement.

Question: A patient with well-controlled epilepsy undergoes cervical spine surgery with MEP monitoring. Subanesthetic ketamine 0.3–0.5 mg/kg/hr is added to propofol/remifentanil TIVA for analgesia. MEP amplitudes increase 35–50%. Which network-level mechanism supports ketamine's MEP-enhancing effect?
OptionA: Direct GABA-A potentiation
OptionB: NMDA receptor antagonism leading to cortical disinhibition and increased glutamatergic drive on motor pathways
OptionC: Mu-opioid agonism
OptionD: Alpha-2 adrenergic sedation
Explanation: Ketamine blocks NMDA receptors on inhibitory interneurons, resulting in net cortical excitation and MEP facilitation at low doses; this contrasts with GABAergic agents and is generally safe in controlled epilepsy (standard anesthesia-IONM literature). Distractor A is incorrect because GABA-A potentiation suppresses MEPs, not enhances them.

Question: A comatose patient 48 hours post-cardiac arrest develops generalized periodic discharges at 1–1.5 Hz on a suppressed background without reactivity. Which prognostic implication and management consideration are most appropriate?
OptionA: Favorable outcome expected
OptionB: Malignant EEG pattern strongly associated with poor neurologic recovery; often represents ictal-interictal continuum with high seizure burden requiring continuous monitoring and consideration of antiseizure therapy
OptionC: Reversible metabolic encephalopathy
OptionD: Benign drowsiness variant
Explanation: GPDs post-anoxia indicate severe cortical injury with dismal prognosis; treatment targets potential nonconvulsive seizures, though outcome benefit remains uncertain (standard critical care EEG guidelines). Distractor C is incorrect because metabolic encephalopathy would show triphasic waves, not periodic discharges.

Question: Long-latency cortical SEP recordings show prominent low-frequency drift obscuring baseline. Which filter setting optimally removes drift while preserving physiologic slow-wave components critical for peak identification?
OptionA: High-pass filter at 30 Hz
OptionB: High-pass filter at 0.1–0.5 Hz with gradual roll-off
OptionC: Low-pass filter at 100 Hz
OptionD: 60 Hz notch filter
Explanation: Very low high-pass filtering eliminates DC and slow drift without attenuating genuine low-frequency cortical SEP content; higher cutoffs would distort morphology (standard evoked potential signal processing). Distractor A is incorrect because a 30 Hz high-pass filter would remove slow waves, not just drift.

Question: A 48-year-old patient with multiple system atrophy-cerebellar type shows progressive ataxia, autonomic dysfunction, and pyramidal signs. MRI demonstrates pontine atrophy with cruciform T2 hyperintensity. Which selective fiber degeneration produces this imaging sign?
OptionA: Corticospinal tract primary loss
OptionB: Degeneration of pontine nuclei and transverse pontocerebellar fibers with relative sparing of longitudinal corticospinal and medial lemniscus tracts
OptionC: Demyelination of dorsal columns
OptionD: Ischemic changes in basis pontis
Explanation: The 'hot cross bun' sign in MSA-C reflects loss of transverse pontine fibers against preserved longitudinal bundles; this correlates with cerebellar outflow disruption (standard neurodegenerative imaging). Distractor A is incorrect because corticospinal tract loss would not produce the cruciform pattern.

Question: A 40-year-old man with aquaporin-4 positive NMOSD develops recurrent longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis. Posterior tibial SEPs show prolonged central conduction times with reduced amplitudes, while median SEPs are normal. Which lesion distribution commonly produces this lower extremity-predominant pattern?
OptionA: Peripheral symmetric neuropathy
OptionB: Thoracic or thoracolumbar cord involvement affecting longer ascending dorsal column pathways
OptionC: Cortical hand area lesion
OptionD: Brainstem only
Explanation: NMOSD lesions are longitudinally extensive and often thoracic; lower extremity pathways are more affected due to length and lesion location, with upper extremity sparing unless cervical involvement (ACNS Guideline on evoked potentials). Distractor A is incorrect because peripheral neuropathy would affect popliteal responses, not just central conduction.

Question: During cerebellopontine angle meningioma resection, free-run facial EMG shows intermittent synchronized A-trains during tumor capsule dissection near the facial nerve root entry zone. Which prognostic significance do A-trains carry compared to sporadic neurotonic discharges?
OptionA: Benign irritation with excellent facial outcome
OptionB: Strong correlation with postoperative facial weakness due to cumulative axonal membrane stress and desynchronization
OptionC: Artifact requiring ignore
OptionD: Indicator of improved nerve function
Explanation: A-trains reflect pathologic synchronous firing from axonal irritation and predict poorer facial prognosis than transient bursts; surgical pause or technique modification is warranted (standard facial nerve monitoring literature). Distractor A is incorrect because A-trains are not benign and are associated with worse outcomes.

Question: Dexmedetomidine 0.5–0.7 µg/kg/hr is infused for sedation during awake craniotomy with direct cortical stimulation mapping. EEG shows anteriorized beta activity, and cortical SEPs/MEPs remain robust. Which central mechanism accounts for this IONM compatibility?
OptionA: GABA-A potentiation causing suppression
OptionB: Alpha-2 adrenergic inhibition of locus coeruleus noradrenergic output producing natural sleep-like state with minimal direct cortical/spinal motor depression
OptionC: Burst suppression pattern
OptionD: Delta wave predominance
Explanation: Dexmedetomidine mimics N2 sleep via noradrenergic modulation while preserving evoked responses, distinguishing it from GABAergic agents (standard awake craniotomy anesthesia). Distractor A is incorrect because GABA-A potentiation suppresses IONM signals, not preserves them.

Question: A patient with advanced hepatic encephalopathy shows generalized triphasic waves with anterior predominance and posterior lag. After treatment with lactulose and rifaximin, the pattern resolves with clinical improvement. Which pathophysiologic association and reversibility characterize this finding?
OptionA: Focal structural lesion
OptionB: Non-specific metabolic encephalopathy reflecting subcortical dysfunction; typically reversible with correction of underlying ammonia elevation
OptionC: Ictal pattern requiring anticonvulsants
OptionD: Benign normal variant
Explanation: Triphasic waves indicate reversible metabolic disturbance in hepatic failure; resolution follows treatment unlike structural or ictal patterns (standard encephalopathy EEG literature). Distractor C is incorrect because triphasic waves are not diagnostic of seizures.

Question: High amplifier gain causes clipping of BAEP stimulus artifact and early waves. Which parameter limitation is primarily responsible for distortion of rapid transients?
OptionA: Sampling rate
OptionB: Slew rate (maximum rate of voltage change)
OptionC: Bit depth
OptionD: Common mode rejection
Explanation: Slew rate determines faithful reproduction of fast voltage swings; saturation distorts peaks despite adequate bandwidth or sampling (standard amplifier specifications). Distractor A is incorrect because sampling rate affects temporal resolution, not peak clipping.

Question: A 52-year-old patient with progressive supranuclear palsy shows vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, axial rigidity, and early falls. Which midbrain structure degeneration disrupts saccadic and pursuit systems?
OptionA: Substantia nigra pars compacta
OptionB: Rostral interstitial nucleus of medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) and related burst neuron circuitry
OptionC: Red nucleus
OptionD: Superior colliculus only
Explanation: Tau pathology in PSP targets riMLF and INC, impairing vertical saccade generation and gaze holding (standard tauopathy neuro-ophthalmology). Distractor A is incorrect because substantia nigra loss causes parkinsonism, not gaze palsy.

Question: A 58-year-old patient with severe vitamin E deficiency develops progressive ataxia, areflexia, and large-fiber sensory loss. Posterior tibial SEPs show prolonged peripheral latencies and markedly reduced central conduction, while median SEPs are less affected. Which combined pathology pattern fits?
OptionA: Pure central dorsal column myelopathy
OptionB: Large-fiber sensory axonopathy with dying-back pattern plus secondary dorsal column degeneration affecting longer lower extremity pathways preferentially
OptionC: Small-fiber predominant
OptionD: Motor neuron disease
Explanation: Vitamin E deficiency causes spinocerebellar tract and large sensory fiber damage with length-dependent axonopathy and central degeneration (standard nutritional neuropathy literature). Distractor A is incorrect because vitamin E deficiency affects both peripheral and central pathways.

Question: During conus medullaris tumor resection for neurogenic bladder, bulbocavernosus reflex (BCR) monitoring shows baseline symmetric responses at 35 ms latency. After tumor removal, BCR amplitude decreases 70% bilaterally with latency prolongation to 48 ms. Which sacral level and clinical implication apply?
OptionA: L5–S1 only
OptionB: S2–S4 pudendal afferent/efferent arc; potential postoperative sacral dysfunction requiring monitoring of bowel and bladder function
OptionC: No clinical relevance
OptionD: Improved reflex arc
Explanation: BCR assesses S2–S4 integrity; significant postoperative changes may reflect edema or stretch with variable recovery of sacral functions (standard sacral neuromonitoring guidelines). Distractor A is incorrect because BCR involves S2–S4, not L5–S1.

Question: Remifentanil continuous infusion is chosen over intermittent fentanyl boluses for long spine cases with MEP monitoring. Which pharmacokinetic property provides superior signal stability?
OptionA: Prolonged context-sensitive half-time
OptionB: Ultra-short context-sensitive half-time via esterase metabolism preventing cumulative motor pathway depression
OptionC: Enhanced MEP suppression
OptionD: Latency prolongation only
Explanation: Remifentanil's rapid clearance avoids fluctuating opioid levels that could variably affect motor excitability (standard TIVA pharmacokinetics). Distractor A is incorrect because prolonged half-time leads to cumulative depression, not stability.

Question: A 24-year-old patient with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy experiences myoclonic jerks triggered by video games. Photic stimulation elicits generalized polyspike-and-wave discharges. Which lifestyle modification is most evidence-based?
OptionA: No change needed
OptionB: Avoidance of flickering visual stimuli, patterned screens, and sleep deprivation to minimize seizure provocation
OptionC: Increased screen time
OptionD: Daily hyperventilation
Explanation: Photosensitive JME requires trigger avoidance and sleep hygiene alongside antiseizure medication (standard idiopathic generalized epilepsy management). Distractor A is incorrect because trigger avoidance is essential for seizure control.

Question: Persistent line-frequency interference contaminates recordings despite low electrode impedances. Which environmental mitigation is most effective and least distorting?
OptionA: Aggressive notch filtering
OptionB: Physical separation of recording leads from power cables with lead twisting to reduce electromagnetic loop area
OptionC: High-pass increase to 100 Hz
OptionD: Gain reduction
Explanation: Source reduction via geometry is superior to notch filtering, which can introduce ringing artifact (standard artifact management). Distractor A is incorrect because notch filtering can distort waveform morphology.

Question: A 68-year-old patient develops rhythmic palatal tremor and oscillopsia after brainstem stroke. MRI shows unilateral inferior olivary hypertrophy. Which disrupted feedback loop causes this delayed phenomenon?
OptionA: Corticospinal
OptionB: Dentato-rubro-olivary triangle (Guillain-Mollaret) with loss of cerebellar inhibition on inferior olive
OptionC: Vestibulocerebellar
OptionD: Nigrostriatal
Explanation: Interruption of dentate-red nucleus-olivary connections leads to transsynaptic olivary degeneration and rhythmic 1–3 Hz activity (standard symptomatic palatal tremor). Distractor A is incorrect because corticospinal tract disruption causes weakness, not palatal tremor.

Question: A 46-year-old with anti-Hu antibody paraneoplastic syndrome develops profound sensory ataxia. SEPs show severely attenuated or absent cortical responses with relatively preserved peripheral amplitudes in some limbs. Which neuronal target explains this pattern?
OptionA: Peripheral axon
OptionB: Dorsal root ganglion neuronopathy causing large-fiber sensory loss and central conduction failure
OptionC: Anterior horn cell
OptionD: Cortical generator
Explanation: Paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathy targets DRG cell bodies, producing severe central sensory pathway disruption with variable peripheral sparing (standard paraneoplastic neuropathy literature). Distractor A is incorrect because peripheral axonopathy would affect peripheral responses, not just central conduction.

Question: Facial nerve MEP latency from transcranial stimulation is 7–9 ms versus 4–6 ms for upper extremity in the same patient. Which anatomic factor contributes most to this difference?
OptionA: Shorter extracranial course
OptionB: Longer pontine segment and peripheral facial nerve length compared to upper limb
OptionC: Identical path length
OptionD: No measurable latency
Explanation: Extended conduction distance and additional peripheral segment prolong facial responses (standard cranial nerve monitoring). Distractor A is incorrect because the facial nerve has a longer extracranial course.

Question: Sufentanil infusion is selected over repeated fentanyl boluses for prolonged cases requiring MEP stability. Which property supports this choice?
OptionA: Shorter duration
OptionB: Smoother plasma levels with reduced peak-trough fluctuation affecting motor pathways
OptionC: Greater suppression
OptionD: Latency only
Explanation: Continuous administration minimizes variability in opioid effect (standard long-case TIVA). Distractor A is incorrect because sufentanil has a longer duration than fentanyl.

Question: Alpha coma pattern post-traumatic brain injury shows widespread unreactive alpha. Which prognostic contrast with spindle coma applies?
OptionA: Excellent outcome
OptionB: Generally poor prognosis compared to reactive spindle coma indicating better brainstem integrity
OptionC: Benign
OptionD: Fully reversible
Explanation: Non-reactive alpha indicates severe cortical damage; spindle coma suggests preserved thalamocortical function (standard coma EEG prognostication). Distractor A is incorrect because alpha coma is associated with poor outcomes.

Question: BAEP high-frequency components require bandwidth preservation. Which low-pass setting is appropriate versus cortical SEP?
OptionA: 30–100 Hz for both
OptionB: 1,000–3,000 Hz for BAEPs to capture Wave V; lower (300–500 Hz) for cortical SEPs
OptionC: No low-pass needed
OptionD: Same for all modalities
Explanation: BAEP neural activity extends to higher frequencies than cortical responses (standard modality-specific filtering). Distractor A is incorrect because 30–100 Hz is too low for BAEPs.

Question: Auditory fibers decussate at multiple levels including trapezoid body. Which binaural processing enables sound localization?
OptionA: No decussation
OptionB: Superior olivary complex computing interaural time and level differences
OptionC: Visual integration
OptionD: Somatosensory
Explanation: Multiple crossings support lateralization (standard auditory pathways). Distractor A is incorrect because auditory fibers do decussate at multiple levels.

Question: A 55-year-old with CADASIL has recurrent lacunes and white matter changes. Which SEP pattern can occur?
OptionA: Normal always
OptionB: Central conduction delay from subcortical tract interruption
OptionC: Peripheral primary
OptionD: No change
Explanation: Small vessel disease affects long tracts (standard hereditary arteriopathy). Distractor A is incorrect because CADASIL can cause central conduction delay.

Question: Central motor conduction time (CMCT) is prolonged in a patient with cervical myelopathy versus normal peripheral conduction. Which segment is implicated?
OptionA: Peripheral nerve
OptionB: Corticospinal tract from motor cortex to anterior horn
OptionC: Neuromuscular junction
OptionD: Muscle
Explanation: CMCT isolates central delay; useful in myelopathy vs radiculopathy differentiation (standard diagnostic MEP). Distractor A is incorrect because peripheral nerve lesions do not affect CMCT.

Question: Volatile agents are avoided in MEP monitoring due to dose-dependent loss. Which alternative regimen?
OptionA: Increase MAC
OptionB: Total intravenous anesthesia with propofol and opioid
OptionC: Nitrous oxide high concentration
OptionD: No anesthesia
Explanation: TIVA provides reliable responses (standard motor monitoring anesthesia). Distractor A is incorrect because increasing MAC worsens MEP suppression.

Question: Mu rhythm in central regions reacts how to movement?
OptionA: Enhancement
OptionB: Blocking or desynchronization with actual or intended movement
OptionC: Seizure evolution
OptionD: Slowing
Explanation: Sensorimotor cortex idling rhythm suppressed by activation (standard normal EEG variants). Distractor A is incorrect because mu rhythm is blocked, not enhanced, by movement.

Question: Averaging 3600 trials versus 900 improves SNR by what factor?
OptionA: No change
Explanation: SNR proportional to square root of averages (standard averaging theory). Distractor C is incorrect because SNR improves by the square root, not the factor itself.

Question: Dorsal spinocerebellar tract origin and representation?
OptionA: Contralateral
OptionB: Ipsilateral lower limb from Clarke's column
OptionC: Upper limb
OptionD: Pain
Explanation: Unconscious proprioception to cerebellum (standard cerebellar input pathways). Distractor A is incorrect because the dorsal spinocerebellar tract is ipsilateral.

Question: MOG antibody disease can cause myelitis with SEP abnormalities. Which pattern?
OptionA: Normal
OptionB: Central conduction delay in affected cord segments
OptionC: Peripheral
OptionD: Cortical only
Explanation: Demyelinating lesions affect long tracts (standard inflammatory demyelination). Distractor A is incorrect because MOGAD can cause central conduction delay.

Question: Triggered EMG threshold 7.5 mA in caution zone. Which management?
OptionA: Proceed unchanged
OptionB: Additional verification with imaging or repositioning consideration
OptionC: Immediate removal
OptionD: Artifact ignore
Explanation: Intermediate thresholds warrant caution and assessment (standard pedicle screw testing). Distractor A is incorrect because proceeding unchanged increases risk.

Question: Etomidate can augment cortical SEP amplitudes when baseline poor. Which application?
OptionA: Routine suppression
OptionB: Selective use for signal optimization in challenging cases
OptionC: MEP abolition
OptionD: Latency reduction only
Explanation: Unique enhancement property (standard IONM anesthesia). Distractor A is incorrect because etomidate is not used for routine suppression.

Question: Occipital intermittent rhythmic delta activity (OIRDA) in pediatric EEG. Which association?
OptionA: Adult normal
OptionB: Common in childhood absence epilepsy
OptionC: Frontal
OptionD: Always pathologic
Explanation: Epilepsy-related pattern in children (standard pediatric EEG). Distractor A is incorrect because OIRDA is not typical in adults.

Question: Low-frequency filter set too high attenuates physiologic delta. Which preserves slow activity?
OptionA: 30 Hz high-pass
OptionB: 0.5–1 Hz high-pass
OptionC: 100 Hz low-pass
OptionD: Notch
Explanation: Appropriate for EEG slow waves (standard filtering guidelines). Distractor A is incorrect because 30 Hz high-pass would remove slow waves.

Question: Spinothalamic tract decussates how?
OptionA: Brainstem
OptionB: Anterior commissure 1–2 segments rostral
OptionC: Thalamic
OptionD: No decussation
Explanation: Contralateral pain/temperature representation (standard anterolateral system). Distractor A is incorrect because spinothalamic tract decussates in the spinal cord, not the brainstem.

Question: B12 deficiency myelopathy can cause central SEP delay. Which tract?
OptionA: Anterior
OptionB: Posterior columns with length-dependent pattern
OptionC: Peripheral
OptionD: Lateral only
Explanation: Subacute combined degeneration (standard metabolic myelopathy). Distractor A is incorrect because B12 deficiency affects posterior columns, not anterior.

Question: D-wave monitoring used primarily in which procedure?
OptionA: Peripheral nerve repair
OptionB: Intramedullary spinal cord tumor resection for direct corticospinal assessment
OptionC: Carotid surgery
OptionD: Epilepsy mapping
Explanation: Axonal integrity evaluation (standard spinal IONM). Distractor A is incorrect because D-wave monitoring is not used in peripheral nerve repair.

Question: Opioids relative to volatiles in MEP monitoring?
OptionA: Greater suppression
OptionB: Less direct effect on motor pathways
OptionC: Latency predominant
OptionD: Amplitude increase
Explanation: Preferred component of TIVA (standard IONM anesthesia). Distractor A is incorrect because volatiles cause greater suppression than opioids.

Question: K-complex in stage N2 sleep characterized by?
OptionA: Seizure discharge
OptionB: High-amplitude negative-sharp wave followed by positive component
OptionC: Sleep spindle
OptionD: Delta burst
Explanation: Arousal-related sleep microstructure (standard sleep staging). Distractor A is incorrect because K-complexes are not seizure discharges.

Question: Impedance mismatch reduces which amplifier performance?
OptionA: Gain
OptionB: Common mode rejection effectiveness
OptionC: Sampling
OptionD: Bandwidth
Explanation: Converts common to differential noise (standard differential amplification). Distractor A is incorrect because impedance mismatch does not directly reduce gain.

Question: Substantia gelatinosa (Rexed lamina II) primary role?
OptionA: Motor output
OptionB: Modulation of nociceptive transmission via local interneurons
OptionC: Proprioception
OptionD: Vibration
Explanation: Gate control and opioid modulation site (standard dorsal horn organization). Distractor A is incorrect because substantia gelatinosa is not involved in motor output.

Question: CADASIL can produce white matter changes with SEP abnormalities. Which mechanism?
OptionA: Large vessel
OptionB: Small vessel arteriopathy disrupting long tract conduction
OptionC: Venous
OptionD: No effect
Explanation: NOTCH3-related subcortical infarcts (standard hereditary small vessel disease). Distractor A is incorrect because CADASIL is a small vessel arteriopathy.

Question: A 58-year-old woman develops right arm and leg weakness with spasticity and hyperreflexia after a small infarct in the left lateral medulla that extends into the lower pons. She also has ipsilateral facial sensory loss and contralateral body pain and temperature loss. Which tract involvement best explains the contralateral motor deficit in this brainstem lesion?
OptionA: Interruption of corticospinal fibers in the pyramid before decussation
OptionB: Involvement of descending corticospinal fibers in the ventral brainstem after decussation, affecting contralateral limb strength
OptionC: Damage to the medial lemniscus carrying contralateral proprioceptive information only
OptionD: Lesion of spinothalamic tract carrying pain and temperature only
Explanation: Corticospinal fibers descend through the ventral brainstem after crossing in the caudal medulla; lateral medullary or pontine lesions that extend ventrally can involve these fibers and produce contralateral upper motor neuron weakness.[web:27]

Question: A 45-year-old man presents with sudden onset of left homonymous hemianopia. He has no motor or language deficits. MRI reveals an isolated right occipital infarct. Which visual pathway structure has been primarily affected?
OptionA: Right lateral geniculate nucleus and optic tract
OptionB: Right optic nerve
OptionC: Right primary visual cortex in the calcarine fissure region
OptionD: Optic chiasm
Explanation: Isolated homonymous hemianopia with preserved motor and language function and a right occipital lesion localizes to the right primary visual cortex (calcarine cortex), which receives retino
input from the contralateral visual field.[web:27]

Question: An intraoperative monitoring system uses a 16-bit analog-to-digital converter (ADC) with a ±100 µV input range. What is the approximate voltage resolution (least significant bit) of this system?
OptionA: About 3 µV per bit
OptionB: About 1.5 µV per bit
OptionC: About 0.003 µV per bit
OptionD: About 0.0015 µV per bit
Explanation: A 16-bit ADC has 65,536 quantization levels; with a ±100 µV range (200 µV total), the resolution is approximately 200 µV / 65,536 ≈ 0.00305 µV per level? Wait, miscalc; correct is 200 µV / 65,536 ≈ 0.003 µV. However, typical clinical systems often use slightly larger ranges; in a ±1000 µV case, resolution is ~0.03 µV. (Note: exact resolution depends on the actual configured range.)[web:20][web:22]

Question: A technologist wants to verify that the BAEP recording system is linear across the expected amplitude range. Which procedure best assesses amplifier linearity?
OptionA: Change display gain and see if the waveform looks larger
OptionB: Inject a series of known calibration pulses of different amplitudes and verify that measured output amplitudes scale proportionally
OptionC: Increase the number of averages and assess noise reduction
OptionD: Change high-pass filters and observe baseline drift
Explanation: Linearity is tested by applying multiple known input signals across the operating range and confirming that output measurements scale linearly with input amplitude, ensuring accurate amplitude interpretation.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 22-year-old woman has generalized tonic–clonic seizures. EEG during wakefulness shows a normal posterior dominant rhythm with sporadic generalized spike–wave discharges at 3–4 Hz. During drowsiness, spike–wave activity becomes more frequent. Which epilepsy type do these findings most strongly support?
OptionA: Focal frontal lobe epilepsy
OptionB: Idiopathic generalized epilepsy
OptionC: Temporal lobe epilepsy from mesial sclerosis
OptionD: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures
Explanation: Generalized spike–wave discharges on a normal background, often accentuated during drowsiness, are characteristic of idiopathic generalized epilepsies such as juvenile absence or generalized tonic–clonic seizures alone.[web:20][web:23]

Question: A 66-year-old man with liver failure and confusion has an EEG showing generalized 1–2 Hz triphasic waves with anterior-posterior lag and background slowing. After lactulose therapy and improved ammonia levels, triphasic waves resolve and the background improves. What is the most appropriate diagnostic implication?
OptionA: Metabolic encephalopathy, particularly hepatic, rather than primary epilepsy
OptionB: Nonconvulsive status epilepticus requiring anesthetic coma
OptionC: Structural temporal lobe epilepsy
OptionD: Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease
Explanation: Generalized triphasic waves with anterior predominance and resolution following metabolic correction are typical of hepatic encephalopathy and other metabolic encephalopathies rather than epileptic seizures.[web:20][web:23]

Question: A 38-year-old woman with progressive sensory ataxia and a positive Romberg test is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency. Posterior tibial SEPs show normal popliteal responses but delayed and low-amplitude lumbar and cortical responses. Median SEPs are mildly delayed centrally. Which diagnosis best fits this pattern?
OptionA: Subacute combined degeneration with dorsal column and corticospinal tract involvement
OptionB: Isolated peripheral neuropathy of the tibial nerves
OptionC: Thoracic radiculopathy only
OptionD: Temporal lobe epilepsy
Explanation: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration affecting dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts; delayed central SEP conduction with normal peripheral responses in the legs and mild upper-extremity involvement are characteristic.[web:41][web:48]

Question: During cervical laminectomy, median SEPs are monitored. After decompression, Erb’s N9 remains stable, N13 increases in amplitude, and N20–P25 complex becomes larger and slightly earlier. MAP and anesthetic depth are constant. Which conclusion is most appropriate?
OptionA: Deterioration of cervical dorsal column conduction
OptionB: Improvement in dorsal column and central somatosensory conduction consistent with effective decompression
OptionC: Anesthetic artifact only
OptionD: Peripheral nerve injury
Explanation: Increased N13 amplitude and decreased N13–N20 latency after decompression indicate improved dorsal column and central conduction, suggesting a favorable surgical effect.[web:30][web:131]

Question: During intramedullary tumor resection at T7, lower extremity MEPs are initially robust. After further resection near the ventral aspect of the tumor, MEPs to both legs abruptly disappear. Epidural D-wave amplitude recorded at T6 decreases from 100% to 85% of baseline and remains stable. SEPs are unchanged. Postoperatively, the patient has severe paraparesis but improves significantly over months. What does this pattern suggest?
OptionA: Severe, permanent transection of corticospinal tracts
OptionB: Preserved corticospinal conduction with reversible segmental motor neuron or synaptic dysfunction, associated with good long-term recovery
OptionC: Pure dorsal column injury
OptionD: Technical failure of MEP stimulation
Explanation: Preserved D-wave amplitude above ~70–80% of baseline indicates intact corticospinal tracts; loss of muscle MEPs with stable D-waves typically reflects transient spinal motor neuron or synaptic dysfunction and correlates with a favorable long-term motor prognosis.[web:24][web:27][web:33]

Question: During C6–C7 anterior cervical discectomy, transcranial MEPs from the right hand muscles decline to 25% of baseline, while left hand and bilateral leg MEPs and SEPs remain stable. MAP and anesthetic depth are unchanged. The surgeon has just placed and tightened the C6–C7 interbody cage and plate. What is the most appropriate next step?
OptionA: Assume anesthetic variability and observe for 30 minutes
OptionB: Alert the surgeon to probable right-sided root or cord compromise at C6–C7 and request immediate inspection and possible adjustment of the hardware
OptionC: Stop MEP monitoring and continue SEPs only
OptionD: Administer muscle relaxant to improve MEPs
Explanation: Focal MEP decline confined to right C7 myotomes with preserved contralateral and leg responses suggests local compromise at the operative level; prompt hardware inspection and correction are indicated to prevent permanent motor deficit.[web:24][web:27][web:33]

Question: A 62-year-old man undergoing thoracic fusion with MEP and SEP monitoring is maintained on propofol 100 µg/kg/min and remifentanil. To manage hypertension, the anesthesiologist adds 0.5 MAC sevoflurane without changing propofol. Ten minutes later, MEP amplitudes are reduced by 70%, while SEPs show minor latency changes. What is the most appropriate anesthetic adjustment?
OptionA: Increase sevoflurane to 1.0 MAC
OptionB: Reduce or discontinue sevoflurane toward 0–0.3 MAC and support anesthesia with propofol and opioids
OptionC: Add nitrous oxide 50%
OptionD: Administer benzodiazepines
Explanation: Volatile anesthetics, especially combined with nitrous oxide, strongly depress MEPs; reducing volatile concentration and relying more on TIVA preserves corticospinal excitability and improves MEP reliability.[web:24][web:27][web:134]

Question: During scoliosis correction with TIVA and MEP monitoring, a dexmedetomidine infusion at 0.5–0.7 µg/kg/hr is started to reduce opioid requirements and improve hemodynamic stability. MEPs and SEPs remain stable. EEG shows spindle-like frontal activity. Which anesthetic property of dexmedetomidine is most responsible for this favorable neuromonitoring profile?
OptionA: Strong GABA agonism causing deep cortical suppression
OptionB: Alpha-2 adrenergic agonism in the locus coeruleus producing a sleep-like state with relatively modest depression of corticospinal and cortical excitability at these doses
OptionC: Direct NMDA antagonism in the motor cortex
OptionD: Neuromuscular blockade
Explanation: Dexmedetomidine produces sedation by alpha-2 agonism in the locus coeruleus, creating a sleep-like EEG pattern with less suppression of MEPs than higher-dose propofol or benzodiazepines, supporting stable neuromonitoring.[web:21][web:27][web:134]

Question: A 42-year-old man with focal seizures has interictal EEG showing left temporal spikes and TIRDA. During a captured seizure, EEG reveals rhythmic 5–7 Hz activity over the left temporal region that increases in amplitude and slows, followed by postictal suppression. Which feature confirms the ictal nature of this temporal rhythm?
OptionA: Fixed frequency without amplitude change
OptionB: Spatiotemporal evolution in frequency and amplitude with postictal suppression
OptionC: Appearance only during drowsiness without clinical correlate
OptionD: Generalized 3 Hz spike–wave pattern
Explanation: Ictal rhythms show evolution in frequency, amplitude, and spatial distribution, often followed by postictal suppression; this differentiates them from non-evolving benign patterns like RMTD or non-ictal slowing.[web:20][web:23]

Question: A technologist notes that SEP waveforms appear noisier than usual. Electrode impedances are all below 3 kΩ and balanced. The primary noise is random and broadband. Without changing stimulus intensity or filters, what is the most effective way to improve signal-to-noise ratio?
OptionA: Decrease the number of averages
OptionB: Increase the number of averaged trials
OptionC: Reduce sampling rate
OptionD: Increase display gain only
Explanation: For random, uncorrelated noise, averaging improves SNR proportional to the square root of the number of trials; increasing the number of averages is the most effective way to improve waveform clarity in this context.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A patient with a complete Brown-Séquard lesion at T8 on the right has motor and proprioceptive deficits below T8 on the right and pain and temperature loss below T8 on the left. Which tract carries the contralateral pain and temperature information affected in this syndrome?
OptionA: Right dorsal columns
OptionB: Right spinothalamic tract, containing crossed fibers from the left side of the body
OptionC: Left spinothalamic tract before decussation
OptionD: Right corticospinal tract
Explanation: Pain and temperature fibers cross near their level of entry via the anterior commissure and then ascend in the contralateral spinothalamic tract; a right hemisection at T8 disrupts left body pain and temperature via the right spinothalamic tract.[web:27]

Question: A 51-year-old man with suspected cervical myelopathy undergoes median SEPs. Erb’s N9 is normal, but N13 and N20 are bilaterally delayed and reduced. Posterior tibial SEPs are also delayed centrally. MRI shows cervical canal stenosis at C4–C5. Which pathophysiology best explains the SEP findings?
OptionA: Isolated lumbar cord lesion
OptionB: Dorsal column dysfunction in the cervical cord affecting long ascending tracts for both upper and lower extremities
OptionC: Peripheral median neuropathy
OptionD: Isolated cortical lesion
Explanation: Normal peripheral but abnormal cervical and cortical components for both upper and lower extremities indicate dorsal column dysfunction at the cervical level, affecting long ascending tracts from both arms and legs.[web:30][web:41][web:131]

Question: During thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair, after cross-clamping above the Artery of Adamkiewicz, bilateral leg MEPs disappear while posterior tibial SEPs remain stable. MAP falls from 85 to 60 mmHg. The team promptly raises MAP to 95 mmHg and places a distal perfusion shunt; MEPs partially recover. Which vascular territory is most implicated in this transient deficit?
OptionA: Posterior spinal arteries supplying dorsal columns
OptionB: Anterior spinal artery supplied in part by the Artery of Adamkiewicz, perfusing corticospinal tracts
OptionC: Middle cerebral artery
OptionD: Vertebral arteries supplying the cerebellum
Explanation: The Artery of Adamkiewicz is a major feeder of the anterior spinal artery; its compromise reduces perfusion of anterior horn cells and corticospinal tracts, leading to selective MEP loss with preserved SEPs that may recover with restoration of anterior cord perfusion.[web:27][web:33]

Question: A 70-year-old man with chronic hypertension undergoes spinal deformity correction with neuromonitoring. To reduce blood loss, the team lowers MAP from 100 to 55 mmHg using nitroprusside. Shortly afterward, leg MEPs decline by 60%, while SEPs are unchanged. What hemodynamic principle is most relevant to this situation?
OptionA: Chronic hypertension shifts autoregulation to lower pressures
OptionB: Chronic hypertension shifts autoregulation to higher pressures, so MAP 55 mmHg may fall below the lower limit of spinal cord autoregulation and risk anterior cord ischemia
OptionC: Spinal cord perfusion is independent of MAP
OptionD: SEPs are more sensitive than MEPs to ischemia
Explanation: In chronic hypertension, the autoregulatory curve is shifted rightwards; aggressive hypotension can lower MAP below the perfusion threshold for the anterior spinal cord, causing MEP changes before SEPs.[web:27][web:33][web:117]

Question: A 30-year-old man with apparent seizures has multiple episodes of asynchronous limb thrashing and pelvic thrusting during video-EEG monitoring. EEG shows only muscle artifact with preserved background and no ictal pattern. He remains partially responsive with eye closure during events. Which management step is most appropriate?
OptionA: Escalate antiseizure medications
OptionB: Diagnose psychogenic non-epileptic seizures and refer for appropriate psychiatric and psychological evaluation
OptionC: Diagnose temporal lobe epilepsy
OptionD: Administer IV benzodiazepines for status epilepticus
Explanation: Events with dramatic motor activity but no ictal EEG change and preserved background strongly support PNES; optimal management includes clear communication of the diagnosis and referral for psychological/psychiatric care rather than antiseizure escalation.[web:20][web:23][web:91]

Question: A technologist recording BAEPs notices that Waves I–V appear broader and latencies seem slightly increased after switching the low-pass filter from 3,000 Hz to 300 Hz. Which technical factor is the most likely cause?
OptionA: True slowing of auditory conduction
OptionB: Attenuation of high-frequency components and phase shift introduced by the narrower low-pass filter, causing broadened and slightly delayed peaks
OptionC: Increased stimulus intensity
OptionD: Improved electrode impedance
Explanation: Lowering the low-pass filter too much attenuates high-frequency components important for the sharp BAEP peaks and can introduce phase distortion, making peaks appear broader and slightly delayed without true physiologic change.[web:20][web:22]

Question: A 50-year-old man has right facial weakness including the forehead, decreased lacrimation, hyperacusis, and loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue on the right. MRI shows enhancement of the facial nerve in the facial canal proximal to the chorda tympani origin. Which branch’s involvement explains the hyperacusis?
OptionA: Greater petrosal nerve
OptionB: Chorda tympani
OptionC: Nerve to stapedius
OptionD: Posterior auricular nerve
Explanation: Hyperacusis in facial nerve palsy reflects paralysis of the stapedius muscle, which is innervated by the nerve to stapedius; lesions proximal to this branch produce hyperacusis along with facial paralysis.[web:27]

Question: During lumbar decompression, posterior tibial SEPs show stable popliteal responses, but lumbar potentials and cortical P37 decrease by 60% bilaterally soon after aggressive retraction of the thecal sac at L2–L3. MAP and anesthesia are unchanged. What is the most likely mechanism?
OptionA: Peripheral tibial nerve compression
OptionB: Mechanical compromise of dorsal roots or dorsal columns at the lumbar level due to retraction
OptionC: Isolated cortical ischemia unrelated to surgery
OptionD: Anesthetic artifact only
Explanation: Stable distal responses with reduced lumbar and cortical components localized to the lumbar spinal level suggest mechanical compromise of dorsal roots or dorsal columns due to retraction at that level.[web:30][web:131]

Question: During resection of a left frontal tumor near the precentral gyrus, direct cortical stimulation evokes contralateral hand movements at 3 mA. As the surgeon continues resection closer to the stimulated area, the threshold needed to evoke movement increases to 10 mA. What is the safest interpretation of this change?
OptionA: Improved safety margin for resection
OptionB: Increased proximity to or partial involvement of primary motor cortex or its subcortical fibers, indicating higher risk of motor deficit if resection is advanced further in that direction
OptionC: Need to stop mapping
OptionD: Anesthetic artifact only
Explanation: Rising thresholds to evoke motor responses during cortical mapping indicate that the resection is approaching or affecting motor cortex or subcortical fibers, signaling increasing risk of motor deficit and prompting caution or trajectory adjustment.[web:27][web:135]

Question: A 59-year-old woman undergoing thoracic decompression with neuromonitoring is hypotensive. The anesthesiologist starts phenylephrine, increasing MAP from 60 to 80 mmHg. MEPs that had been reduced by 50% partially recover. Which pharmacologic property of phenylephrine is most relevant to this improvement?
OptionA: Central GABAergic sedative effect
OptionB: Peripheral alpha-1 agonism increasing systemic vascular resistance and MAP, thereby enhancing spinal cord perfusion
OptionC: Direct enhancement of corticospinal excitability
OptionD: NMDA antagonism
Explanation: Phenylephrine is a peripheral alpha-1 agonist that increases systemic vascular resistance and MAP; improved spinal cord perfusion with higher MAP can restore MEP amplitudes in cases of hypoperfusion-related decline.[web:27][web:134]

Question: A 16-year-old girl with photosensitive epilepsy undergoes EEG with intermittent photic stimulation. At flash frequencies of 15–20 Hz, generalized spike–wave discharges appear, accompanied by eyelid myoclonus. Outside of photic stimulation, EEG is normal. Which recommendation is most appropriate?
OptionA: No lifestyle changes are necessary
OptionB: Avoid flickering lights, strobe effects, and certain video games with rapidly changing visual patterns
OptionC: Stop all exercise
OptionD: Wear eye patches permanently
Explanation: A photoparoxysmal response indicates photosensitivity; patients should avoid exposure to flickering stimuli and strobe lights that can trigger seizures, including certain video games and club environments.[web:20][web:23]

Question: A BAEP system uses clicks at 100 dB nHL. The neurophysiologist requests reducing intensity to 70 dB nHL to minimize cochlear trauma risk. How will this likely affect BAEPs in a normal-hearing patient?
OptionA: Increase in amplitude of Waves I–V
OptionB: Decrease in BAEP amplitudes with slight latency prolongation, especially for Waves I and III
OptionC: Complete abolition of BAEPs
OptionD: No change at all
Explanation: Lower click intensity reduces neural recruitment and prolongs cochlear and brainstem response latencies, leading to smaller BAEP amplitudes and slightly delayed peaks, particularly at Wave I and III.[web:22][web:27]

Question: A 47-year-old man has weakness and spasticity in the right leg greater than the arm, with a Babinski sign on the right. MRI reveals a small stroke in the left medial frontal cortex involving the paracentral lobule. Which body region’s motor representation is primarily affected?
OptionA: Contralateral face
OptionB: Contralateral leg
OptionC: Ipsilateral arm
OptionD: Trunk only
Explanation: The paracentral lobule on the medial surface of the frontal lobe contains the leg area of primary motor cortex; lesions here cause contralateral leg-predominant weakness and upper motor neuron signs.[web:27]

Question: During posterior fossa surgery with BAEP and median SEP monitoring, BAEP Wave V amplitude on the left decreases by 65% and latency prolongs by 1.2 ms after cerebellar retraction. Median SEPs remain stable. What is the most appropriate interpretation?
OptionA: Cervical dorsal column injury
OptionB: Compromise of left brainstem auditory pathways, likely at the level of the pons or midbrain, due to surgical manipulation
OptionC: Global anesthetic effect
OptionD: Peripheral median neuropathy
Explanation: Left BAEP Wave V changes with stable SEPs indicate focal dysfunction in left brainstem auditory pathways from the cochlear nucleus upward, commonly due to retraction or vascular compromise in posterior fossa procedures.[web:22][web:30][web:131]

Question: During scoliosis correction, bilateral leg MEPs are monitored. After rod derotation, MEPs from the right leg muscles decline by 80%, while left leg MEPs and SEPs remain unchanged. MAP and anesthetic depth are stable. The surgeon partially reverses the correction; right leg MEPs recover to 60% of baseline. Which course of action is most appropriate regarding deformity correction?
OptionA: Proceed with full correction despite MEP changes
OptionB: Accept a lesser degree of correction that preserves MEPs to minimize risk of permanent neurologic deficit
OptionC: Ignore MEPs and rely on SEPs only
OptionD: Stop all neuromonitoring
Explanation: Unilateral MEP decline related to correction maneuvers suggests mechanical compromise of that side’s cord or roots; partial reversal that restores MEPs supports accepting a lesser correction to prioritize neurologic safety.[web:24][web:27][web:33]

Question: A 63-year-old woman undergoing thoracic tumor resection with MEP monitoring is slightly tachycardic. The anesthesiologist starts a low-dose esmolol infusion. MEP amplitudes and SEPs remain stable. Which advantage does esmolol offer compared with longer-acting beta-blockers in this context?
OptionA: Produces long-lasting hypotension that stabilizes MEPs
OptionB: Short half-life allows rapid titration and reversal if blood pressure falls and neuromonitoring suggests compromised spinal cord perfusion
OptionC: Acts as a potent MEP stimulant
OptionD: Induces burst-suppression on EEG
Explanation: Esmolol’s ultra–short half-life and beta-1 selectivity permit quick adjustment or discontinuation if hypotension develops and neuromonitoring reveals compromised perfusion, enhancing intraoperative safety.[web:21][web:27][web:134]

Question: A 28-year-old woman with nocturnal spells undergoes video-EEG. Sleep shows high-amplitude centrotemporal spikes with a horizontal dipole, often activated by drowsiness and NREM sleep, but no clear ictal pattern is recorded. Neurologic exam is normal. Which syndrome is most consistent with this EEG finding?
OptionA: Benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS)
OptionB: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
OptionC: Temporal lobe epilepsy
OptionD: Metabolic encephalopathy
Explanation: BECTS is characterized by high-amplitude centrotemporal spikes with a horizontal dipole, often activated in sleep, in neurologically normal children or adolescents with nocturnal focal seizures.[web:20][web:23]
